iconography.form_here: Standing posture (sthanika) on lotus, four-armed. The idol is entirely black (due to camphor and kasturi application over centuries), standing 6 feet tall without pedestal. Uniquely, the eyes appear differently to different devotees.

symbolism.chakra: Discus - represents the mind, time-cycle, and protection
symbolism.left_lower_hand: Kati hasta - hand on hip, signifying world support
symbolism.namam: Vertical forehead mark - represents Vishnu's footprint
symbolism.eyes: Said to appear open/closed based on devotee's faith

special_ornaments.neela_devi_hair: Deity wears wig of donated hair since original was damaged
special_ornaments.vaksha_sthala_lakshmi: Lakshmi's form is embedded on the chest

mythology.origin_story: In Satya Yuga, the sages of Bhrigu lineage cursed both Brahma and Shiva (for pride), leaving only Vishnu as the supreme worshipable god. When Bhrigu tested Vishnu by kicking his chest, Lakshmi (who resides there) was insulted and left for Earth. Vishnu followed, taking birth as Srinivasa, eventually settling in Tirumala to be near Lakshmi (who incarnated as Padmavati).

key_episodes.title: The Kubera Loan
key_episodes.story: To marry Padmavati (incarnation of Lakshmi), Vishnu needed enormous wedding funds. He borrowed from Kubera—god of wealth—at interest. This 'debt' is symbolically being repaid through devotee donations until the end of Kaliyuga.

key_episodes.title: Neela Devi's Hair
key_episodes.story: A shepherd's axe accidentally struck Vishnu's head, causing a bald patch. Neela Devi, a Gandharva princess, sacrificed her own hair to cover it. In gratitude, Vishnu allowed devotees to offer hair forevermore. Hence the tonsure tradition.

key_episodes.title: The Ant-Hill Manifestation
key_episodes.story: Vishnu stood motionless in meditation for so long that anthills grew over him. A cowherd's cow poured milk over the anthill daily. When the king investigated, he found the divine form—Swayambhu (self-manifested).

primary_mantra.meaning: A simple invocation connecting the devotee to the Lord Who Destroys Sins

popular_chant.context: Shouted by pilgrims throughout the darshan queue. Govinda = one who gives pleasure to cows/senses = Vishnu/Krishna

offerings: Cash donations (to repay the cosmic debt)
Laddus made with ghee, gram flour, cardamom

festivals.name: Brahmotsavam
festivals.significance: Main annual festival. Deity processes on different vahanas (mounts). Millions attend.

festivals.name: Vaikuntha Ekadashi
festivals.significance: Gates of heaven (Vaikuntha) open. Passing through the temple's Vaikuntha Dwaram grants liberation.

festivals.name: Thai Poosam
festivals.significance: Constellation when Vishnu's energy is at peak. Major crowd surge.

philosophy.core_teaching: Balaji represents accessible grace. Unlike stern, renunciation-focused traditions, Tirupati theology says: 'Come as you are. Ask for what you need. God understands material struggles.' This is 'Kaliyuga Dharma'—in the age of moral decline, sincere devotion alone is sufficient for divine help.
philosophy.the_transaction: Some criticize Tirupati as 'transactional' devotion. Temple philosophy embraces this: 'Yes, devotees make deals. Yes, they come for wishes. The point is—they come. God doesn't require purity of motivation. Interface with the divine, through any door, transforms over time.'
philosophy.surrender: Sharanagati (absolute surrender) is the ultimate teaching. The long queues, the brief darshan, the sacrifice of hair—all are designed to break ego and enforce surrender. By the time you reach the deity, you've given up control. That's the point.
